We hit this place for lunch at around 2:00 pm, I've heard of the place however since I've never been to the original in NY I can't compare it. The menu says they charge $3.00 for plate sharing??, He ordered the hot pastrami on rye and ordered a plate of fries. The server placed 2 glasses of water and a bowl of pickles on table. I'm not really a pickle fan but I was hungry so they tasted quite good not to tart and very fresh and flavorful. Pastrami arrived and all I could say was OMG WTF it's a fuck-in pound of meat on two pieces of bread???, plate of fries arrive promptly. We spit the sandwich and fries. fries were your basic fries nothing specular no fireworks etc. The pastrami was tender, fat free, no grizzle and very flavorful. nothing like what I get at the delis or the Hat. We gave it out best to finish the pastrami, we both left about 3 bites and 1/4 lb of pastrami on the plate. Service from the day crew was great.  Damage: food $24.00, tax $2.00 tip $5.00   We also tried this place at 2;30 AM after a night of gambling,singing dancing,drinking and who knows what else. DH wanted the pastrami again. I opted for breakfast since it was the early morning hours so I got the eggs over-easy with fries (for DH) and wheat toast for me. Pastrami arrived promptly, for some reason they gave our water and pickles to the drunk gals next to us who ordered desert??? My over-easy eggs arrived scramble, i asked the female server if these were over-easy after much eye rolling, she said she be right back. My food arrived after DH polished off 1/2 his sandwich. Asked for a side of mayo to dip my fries in which arrived after I ate 2 eggs and my fries were cold. Sandwich was good, my $8.95 breakfast was not the best I've had.  Damage: $24.00, tip $3.00 off to bed to sleep for 3 hours before we had to catch our flight....

ksr8XUXUSn4IWnCGZI1Ueg.text: i had an aweful experience at this place.  First, my boyfriend's food came out before mine.  and 10 minutes later, after my boyfriend was almost done eating, my food still hadn't come out.  All I ordered was the grilled cheese.  when the waitress realized, she told me my hamburger was on it's way.  I had to correct her to tell her I ordered the grilled cheese and not a hamburger.  When she finally brought my food, she told me that the grilled cheese had come out, but she didn't see a tomato in it so she didn't think it was mine.  Funny, why would she then say my hamburger was on it's way?  Another issue is that she kept saying she'd get me more water after I told her numerous times I ordered an iced tea.  I can understand if it was super busy and that's the reason why she was making mistakes, but it wasn't.  Also, it cost over $40 for a turkey sandwich, grilled cheese with tomato, sparkling water (no refill) and iced tea.  If you're gonna charge customers that much money for a freaking sandwich, then at least provide some sort of service.

FArznYHRpedkJgOc7YwTww.text: Like I died and went to NYC! Former BKLYN girl who's been living in Fl. way too long is in shock to find a Carnegie Deli at the Mirage in Vegas! And the timing was perfect. We had just finished seeing Love, and were absolutely famished. Only a few steps away we see Carnegie. Was I dreaming? Finally, I was getting lucky in vegas! Lucky again; no wait for a table. And lucky one more time; a great waiter AND he was from BKLYN! A corned beef sandwich just tastes better when served to you by a guy with a Bklyn accent. Not even bothering to read the menu, we order a corned beef sand. Full well knowing the size, we decide to share one. That's the only way to save room for the strawberry cheesecake. I expected the food to be great, and it certainly was. What I did not expect was how completely authentic it was. Down to the half sour pickles on the table, and the chocolate eggcream! Carnegie came through with a perfect copy of their original; way to go! Yous are the best!

dKeCBGgUIxCXecBS3LIi2Q.text: What's the difference between this Carnegie Deli and the other reviews page?  I didn't get to try this place in NYC but here in Vegas, you can get any kind of food imaginable from anywhere. Anyways we were stuffed from lunch so we picked up something to go later in the night. One sandwich could easily fill the bellies of two. But since we weren't that hungry, we ended up with some leftovers. Luckily our hotel had a mini fridge and we were able to save some for the next day. We ended up with a pastrami sandwich. I was eyeing their most famous corned beef and pastrami combo sandwich but just thinking of the size of that and at $20, I just couldn't do it. Although the plain pastrami was already $17. Sandwich was fixed up pretty quickly and we were on our way. Oh and we got a choice of breads but  stuck with the typical rye. Man the 'wich was huge. No way could the height of it fit in my mouth.  But wow, really flavorful without being too salty. And moist too. Some fat in the meat too which is bad for my health but makes it takes oh so yummy. A lot of deli's have either really salty pastrami or dry, no flavor meat. This was a good balance. It also came with the necessary (two) pickles and the pickle really helps with a different texture and taste to break up all that meat you're devouring. Wow, not sure I could part with almost 20 bucks for a sandwich all the time but this hit the spot this one time. And you should splurge every once in a while, especially on vacation.

J2MDXMMGIciw5xdd4N4z1Q.text: I love the Carnegie Deli on Seventh Avenue. Don't much care for this place. Tried to order the tongue sandwich on the menu and was told "we're out of tongue. This was the second time so I asked the waitress if they ever had it, and she admitted they didn't. 1) What kind of a Jewish deli doesn't have tongue? And 2) What does it say about management that is willing to put something on a menu that they have no intention of carrying, presumably just to look authentic. Matzoh ball soup wasn't bad, but unless you are already in the Mirage don't go out of your way to eat here.

nZu7AhweSHZKQKBOO7yr5Q.text: Great combo value. Half sandwich which U.S. Like a normal one, matzo ball soup and drink for $14. Carnegie quality. Pastrami just like NYC branch  Clean and friendly service. Open 24-7. What else do you need?

V9UShZuRrEXl6JbcveDMxA.text: I agree with the more recent postings that they have ruined this place. I left a few messages for their Vice-President of Food and Beverage with the Mirage, since I believe they own this location and did not hear back. The General Manager has not addressed any of our concerns as well. I will post a good riddance when the place closes in a year.

fjIpD3UvoV0NsIgK3-tT8g.text: Visited over the holidays with my family and fiance.  We ordered a variety of deli sandwiches and their matzo ball soup.  The quality of the food isn't as good as you'd find in a NYC deli, they make up for the difference in good service and portions.  Things are a little bit on the expensive side for what you get - but not at all unreasonably so for Vegas.  All in all, I'd rate them 3/5 for food, 4/5 for service and 4/5 for quantity.

T82xmcRkyMSsWAWvTZmidA.text: I recommend getting the half sandwich option if you go here. As another reviewer mentioned, the full sandwiches are big enough for two.   I had the roast beef sandwich and fries. The fries were made to order so they were fresh and hot when they came out. The sandwich had something to be desired. I love a good sandwich and I felt like this one was going for quantity over quality. I took some of the meat off of the sandwich just so that i could pick it up. The taste was good, but I have had better tasting sandwiches. The price for what you get really isn't too bad for being in the casino.

H2Ywur4cNsDJyF3Qdp4slA.text: While the entrees are expensive, they are large and delicious. We had breakfast there and did not leave hungry. The cheesecake is exquisite, and they have a convenient take-out counter for desserts. The service was decent, but it was very busy when we were there. Sausage omelet and homefries were worth coming back for.

M0EoqEcyz9nrgx9zYoae6g.text: Not exactly like Carnegie Deli in NY. Love the fries. Both the sandwich and cheesecake were lacking the same punch compared to NY deli. There are better places to go on the strip. This place is average.

w_MPKodAByifzU4oJTdN2w.text: We went to Carnegie Deli on a Monday morning (around 10:30am) for breakfast. The service was extremely slow considering the place wasn't even full. Although, once our orders were taken the food was brought out quickly (although I had to sit and wait for her to bring syrup for the french toast). My boyfriend got an omlete sandwich, which he loved. Just about everything on the breakfast menu included eggs, which isn't so good for a girl whose #1 biggest dislike is eggs. The french toast, which was delcious by the way, was the ONLY breakfast entree without eggs involved. So, good thing I like french toast.   I probably would have given this a better review under one of the two following conditions: a) the service wasn't terrible (she even cut me off mid-sentance when I was ordering) b) I liked eggs and/or they had more than eggs on the breakfast menu  I've had the cheesecake from the Carnegie in New York and if they use the same receipe in Vegas, it has to be amazing. Wish I had left room in my belly to get a piece.

0qSMfGMhPWBy_s5YfIJ5Aw.text: I've eaten at the REAL Carnegie Deli in NY. This is a poor imitation. T0 me there are three measures for a good (Jewish) deli. 1) Corned beef sandwich, 2) Roast beef sandwich, and 3) chicken noodle soup with matzah balls. I had #2. I asked the cashier (I ordered takeout) if the roast beef was rare (there is really no other way to enjoy it). She said it was. I took her word ... my mistake. It was well done with not a hint of pink anywhere ... it was gray-brown. To make matters worse, the meat had a mealy texture ... ewww. The rye was fresh though with a nice hard crust and soft innards. But I couldn't get past the meat. No kosher garlic pickles were included in the order? Why not? IMHO, rare roast beef should be bright red throughout and have a wet texture from being freshly sliced. Some "blood" (not really blood0 should remain on the plate if you put a slice down for a sec. [Bud's deli in Sacramento slices their RB in front of you, and it's absolutely perfect]. I may go back to try a corned beef sandwich or the soup ... but at $20 for my sandwich, it will definitely be a gamble (the restaurant is in the Mirage hotel and casino).

ZrG3nkgocq96JTRhxWfgpw.text: Bread pieces full of meat, meat and more meat...that is the basics of their sandwiches.  You get all that for nearly $20.  Everything else you want on the side or to drink is extra. I don't know, I guess I don't get the hype about it.  Really, people have not had any better pastrami or corned beef anywhere else...really?  So hard to believe.

s9qDHBlRPJiw_iKV5iCjKA.text: Not as good as the New York Original, but OK for a foodie in need while in Las Vegas.   I was sicker than a dog with a chest cold this past Spring Break, and my husband and I braved the line at the Carnegie so I could get some Matzo Ball Soup. My husband had his usual of the mile high Pastrami Sandwich, and I ingested two bowls of Matzo Ball Soup. Yes, two bowls... When you are that sick, the thought of eating on previous days was not appealing. All it took was that golden bowl of broth and Matzo to make me feel a little bit better for the day.   The food was great as per usual at Carnegie. However, being in a smokey casino kind of sucked. The servers are also really rude but they had lines wrapped around the place. So I guess they were just worn out and short with people as per usual.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My husband and Pastrami - Happiness Found in Vegas...
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken Matzo Ball Soup

iboCORsjZmpd97P_kgtxLQ.text: Cheesecake only review!  The truffle cheesecake was flippin' amazing!!  Our group of 3 devoured that in a couple of minutes-mm just the right amount of fluff, sweetness, and sugar!  The blueberry was pretty good, considering I'm not a big fan of blueberries.  It's $10 for a huge slice, but it's well worth it.

8i2Nu_OZ8cwON3je7pCs6w.text: 3.5. The sandwiches are pretty good if you just get the meat one ie for lunch.   The breakfast sandwiches are disappointment.  I felt I wAs eating an egg sandwich. We're was the corned beef?     Buddy said he got sick off his

Ib9OzewsX7YVEcr0JRzgJQ.text: Good, but spendy. I guess like everything in Vegas, bigger is better. We went here never having been to the NY location. I ordered the chicken matzo ball and noodle soup and blintzes, and wasn't disappointed in the blintzes. The matzo balls were great, but the soup needed a bit more substance to it. It was mostly broth (homemade, I think) with matzo balls and noodles. Hubby and the friend both ordered the huge open-face reuben sandwiches. They were delicious, but crazy big. The corned beef was awesome and even though I wasn't sure about it being totally smothered in cheese, it tasted great. We all ate till we were stuffed and walked out with enough leftovers for another meal for all three of us.  Service was a little on the slow side, but they were pretty busy. Only other complaint is that the restaurant itself was sort of cramped- the tables were all really close together.

UAOodLbrgp9qSpoYDa1H5w.text: Yum!!!! Bacon grilled cheese sandwich is the best hangover cure ever! Not the huge sandwich everything else is here, but still has huge taste!  Hope you have a fridge I your room cuz anything else you order here sandwich wise, you'll have leftovers. Pickles, specialty bottled soda, latkes and cakes are all amazing here.

9GCa4Yupr5z3u4HDKhLrRA.text: This place can be summed up in a sentence: Quantity over Quality.  Actually, I don't think that's technically a sentence. Don't you need an object and a proposition or a predicamacation and a subjugation or some shit like that in order for it to technically be a sentence? I don't know, English is my second language. Anyway, this place, huge ass servings, key word, ass. Because that's what everything tasted like. Too dry, too salty, too much. My mom ordered the club sandwich. The thing was several inches tall. Don't believe me? Check out the picture I uploaded. You know how they normally use toothpicks to hold sandwiches together? Well, this place used like chopsticks or something. And it's not like they charge the price of a regular club, they definitely charge you more. But who can eat that much? Especially a little old Asian lady like my mom? Poor woman could barely lift the damn thing up off the plate!  Anyway, if you want to be mesmerized by sheer portion size, eat here. Otherwise, pay less for higher quality food and save your money for one of those topless dance shows in town. Oh yeah.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. animals were hurt in the making of this sandwich

J0OhyIwvZIXuqI7Cr9x9xQ.text: I know $20 for a sandwich seems like a lot, but trust me....it is worth every penny.  Especially when it comes with 2 lbs of meat between 2 slices of regular rye bread.   I can never decide between the pastrami or corned beef because I love both so much, but Carnegie has the perfect solution--the Woody Allen. For $15.95 you get half-pastrami, half-corned beef. It will feed you for a week. My strategy is to take the top slices of bread and skim a few slices of meat to make a mini-sandwich, but believe me there is nothing nothing mini about it. Slather on some russian dressing and prepare your mouth for heart attack heaven.  This is the best pastrami EVER!

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. now this is a sandwich

N4GELIrvsguH6UHrOapqvw.text: I have been to the original Carnegie's in NYC, so it's hard to compare this one to that, but it was okay at best.  Very expensive for what you get.  The server asked if we wanted lettuce and tomato with our sandwich.  I said, "Does it cost extra?"  She responded, "Honey, EVERYTHING costs extra here!!"  She wasn't joking.  A plain roast beef sandwich and fries cost us $25!!  Officially classify it as a tourist trap.  Walk across the hall to BLT Burger and thank me later :)

j-fZmmOc_Bf_GJzvtVzZig.text: Ate here late night.  Ordered Steak & eggs.  Liked that I could substitute the potatoes for sliced tomatoes.  Decent eats. Nothing spectacular. Staff is friendly. If your at the Mirage looking for something to eat it's something.

2Q6l4fbB-cdA7YRaEKmxyQ.text: First of all, it already took long to get seated so we were ready to chow down. Then, it took quite a long time to receive our orders. What's ridiculous is in order to split a meal with a friend, they charge an extra $3. No, you don't receive more meat, bread, or vegetables. The meat was way too salty and the wait was ridiculous.   Apparently they are supposed to model after the New York restaurant but it fails in comparison. We then got our pastrami sandwich and the meat was hard to chew, in fact it tasted a little strange. People here were very unfriendly, come on you're in Sin City, live a little.   People come here to gamble, go clubbing, and eat well. I don't think Carnegie would satisfy the eat well category. Compared to many restaurants in the area, I don't think it would be in my top 10.

WE2BO2YGggVpEZcO-T8K7g.text: Carnegie Deli. Oh you delicious bastard. Located in The Mirage hotel, this is one of the only Mirage restaurants we tried worthy of our hard earned money. From ordering at the counter to waiting for your food, it's max 5 minutes. The pastrami is mind blowing. The half and half combo is a good deal. AND out of all the restaurants we tried at The Mirage, the service here is the best. Not snooty, not chatting their life away, just plain good service. If I was staying at The Mirage and didn't want to leave the hotel, I would definitely eat here again.

MT_zVYnWEA4jEV0iz1Sy5g.text: Our server, Katie, was very nice.  As much as I wanted to try one of their sandwiches, we went in just to have some dessert before our show.  Hubby's banana cream pie was delicious and HUGE, and my chocolate mouse cheesecake combo was awesome.  Sooo much food that I couldn't even finish my slice, as much as I wanted to.    We would go back!

feQXnXh7q2EBdq013zyoEw.text: Definitely not worth the money - even in Vegas. The guy that took our order, Mihai, was flat out hateful. We will never return. Not very good and really over-priced.

5a_1edj15sZ7SrJxZ3aG6A.text: Apple pie looked impressive, but no flavor. My mom and I make better. Bagel was good.

ZwfjgbffMkt5fTRLgbcRtQ.text: Sweet Lord have mercy. I ordered the legendary Woody Allen--described on the menu as "lotsa pastrami and lotsa corned beef"-and the waitress brought a three-pound behemoth that left uninitiated diners slack-jawed.  A couple walked in, sat down one row over. The guy clearly asked his lady, "how hungry are you?" After she gave my beastly meal one of those awkward over-the-shoulder "Doot dee deedle doo I'm not looking at anything behind me" glances, both got up and walked out.  Literally a minute later, a manly conventioneer wandered in and sat down facing my six-inch wonder. His gentlemanly ways quickly melted and he beelined for the exit, screaming like the audience in Scary Movie--"SHEEEEEEEEEET!  OH, HELL NO!  UNT-UH!"  $3 surcharge for sharing...and sharing will definitely be necessary if you want to finish a monster like mine.  As for the quality of the meats? Not bad, not great. Sorta dry. Would I go again?  Yes...but not by myself!  On the plus side, it is very easy to access Carnegie from the strip--look for the covered walkway immediately between Caesars and Mirage.

_U3zoEW0ZUyvstuUG89BSg.text: WOW....what a big disappointment to a meal and experience I was looking SO forward to.  it's not NY and it started bad from the time we waited in line to order.  Order person was lame, we got a table and waited 40 minutes for our food.  I'm not exaggerating, 40 minutes, the watiress felt bad and said we got the shift change.  What does that mean?  Then we had to take it to go b/c we were so late for our daughter's game.  The order was terrible.  We open the bag and our $15. sandwich was so wimpy, not piled up like all the other tables that we saw.  BIG DISAPPOINTMENT DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY OR TIME.

yafaUeMLeOy8amln4yTPXg.text: Terrible. Just terrible. $45 for an egg sandwich and corned beef hash. Filthy tables everywhere. 25 mins before we had to ask where our food was. Then my wife's food magically appears while I had to wait for them to cook the sandwich. Had to ask for silverware as well. Too bad I have to give this place any stars. It's awful. Never again.

lDdrg3svzwx76w900tjy0w.text: It's an old fashioned Delhi, their sandwiches are huge. 1 sandwich is easily enough for two people

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Reuben sandwich

vOHyu1GJ-ekaP9jqvR_ZfA.text: Not worth it.  It costs $8 for a chicken noodle soup. Funny thing is, there's no chicken. None. Basically you get chicken broth with noodles. $8. I wished they called it chicken brother with noodles because I wouldn't have ordered it if that was the case.  However, the service was very good.

GS_XGLgxjSf4nGH1KRSnJQ.text: Good meat sandwiches that work well after a long night of drinking. The nyc style of the counter,  the entry,  the black and white tiled floor is all great.   I've had both the corned beef and the pastrami. Pastrami is much better. I had the corned beef hash too. It says comes with a fried egg. But when I ordered it no fried egg. The server then said that you have to actually request the egg specifically - even though it says it comes with a fried egg. I guess I should just be happy that it came with beef despite my not requesting it. Also it doesn't come with bread - so it's just a pile of chopped beef and oily potatoes. Pass.  Try the burger place across the way instead. If you're on a corporate account then I goes this is Ok.   Slow service, mediocre food and high prices make this no better than your typical mirage hotel restaurant.  Try to avoid unless you can't avoid it.

a3ajlDr1PviIzirJJKkjTA.text: I ate here just because of the convenience factor, but the food was way overpriced and very dry. Also, the bus boy spilt scalding hot coffee over my hand and the table and didn't say anything. He came back with a few napkins and placed them on the table and didn't clean it up. Manager wasn't much help and didn't really do anything. If I was the manager, I would of made the meal complimentary and apologized profusely.   Luckily the waiter was a decent guy so I still gave a decent tip. I wouldn't recommend this place to any friends and the customer service needs some work.

lzJg1PZahuagPC8S9l3Deg.text: Service was bad from the beginning. The lady that took our order was rude, and not helpful. I ordered a Hard salami sandwich, and the salami tasted like bologna, and was not good. I asked the manger Gillis Johnson if I could get a pastmi sandwich instead, and with an attitude she told me that I need to pay the difference, wich I agreed to. Gillis the rudest person in this horrible restaurant never talked to me regarding the extra $2 I need to pay for the pastrami sandwich. The pastrami sandwich was dry, and lacked flavor also, but I ate it anyways because I was hungry, and did not want to talk to the horrible manager again. Then I seen that they charged me $17 for the pastrami, and did not refund my money for the salami sandwich that I did not eat. I called back Gillis, and she is not refunding my money for the sandwich. Very unprofessional. They stole money from me basically! I will be calling my bank to get my money back, but this should have never happened. Would not return to this place ever! Worst deli on the strip!

Qc1RpeZPzotc1mENrTEnmQ.text: So Ruben, max meat, so wow.  Could have used more flavor.  The sandwich was massive, but the flavor was not.    Definitely get a slice of cheese cake and prepare for sticker shock

GSI-O_QLTnIr625lZIg8Og.text: Love the pickles!!!! BLT I swear is a whole pig! So much bacon! Pastrami is very good but could use some cheese. I'd come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. BLT

0LWZbUYUZwKs6kD7xLFEcw.text: All I can say is....If you have been to the Carnegie deli in New York skip this place.   They have no pickled tomatoes, the corned beef was plentiful, but fatty/tough (so go for the turkey), the break was okay, but not great either.  How hard is it to make a sandwich when that is nearly all you make.  Won't come again.  Afterward I heard  from other friends/family that they felt the same way and wished I knew before I wasted my money and time.

zsjgUrAO7dYr81Uj83dT8Q.text: I love this place. Always have at least one breakfast or lunch in this cafe. Food is tasty portions are huge , usually we shearing. Best cheesecakes . Sometimes it's packed and service a little slow but I don't mind to wait a little. And it's open 24 hours, which is a big plus in Vegas.

q8JShO0F95CG6L2AQpqhMQ.text: Great food great service. Huge portions! Under $20 bucks you get a sandwich that makes almost 2 meals. It also wasn't super crowded.

fe7cHRoNe8QlJKVruOgspg.text: The Carnegie of Las Vegas used to be one of my favorite restaurants, a must go when you are in Vegas. Now they have turned a very good restaurant into a fast food experience, you have to pay at the counter and they'll bring your food to your table, you're paying a full price for a fast food restaurant. Also the portions are smaller and the service is bad. I am angry, because they turned a good restaurant into garbage fast food like food overpriced. Plus 11.62 for one piece of cheesecake its obscene.

SjLrNu7MCtMZDsxrj0eHqA.text: A $24 Reuben? Hell yes! I barely finished my half of it and my wife didn't come close lol! Very good and worth it. The big sandwiches easily feed two. Can't wait to go back!

6LLIOcCRLogSQse1FkU6dA.text: HUGE portion of corned beef hash was the best I've ever had. Blueberry cheesecake was also excellent but the chocolate chip cookie was below average. Great service from the waiter but not so much from the bakery counter.

3PU5tu-lSLD4Qm5BwjvaAQ.text: This is one of the worst deli's I have ever  eaten in. Go else where to have a tasty meal:):)  We had 8 people in our party so we ate a lot of different food. Let's start our dinner review:  Good:  1.  Homemade pickles were excellent.  2.  Mindie's Egg Cream was good.  3.   French Fries were good, hot and not greasy.  Bad:  1.  Wait staff was angry and was not responsive to our needs.  2.  Pastrami was excessively dry.  3.  Burgers seemed like they were frozen and thawed.  4.  Giant Hot Dog was not Kosher.  5.  Stouffer's frozen meat loaf has more flavor than Carnegie's Deli Meat Loaf.  6.  Cost is excessive compared to the flavor.  You would do better to go elsewhere to eat.   If this is associated with the Carnegie Deli in New York someone needs to come clean this place up.  This place is the absolute pits:(:(  Go eat at The Firehouse Subs or Red Robin.  Service and quality of food is better.

Uh-39YgcoS9BUF7dcwyp7A.text: Disappointed with the food and price of this restaurant.  Their sandwhiches are huge, too the point of being hard to handle and eat.  If you decide to eat the whole thing you are pretty much deciding to put yourselft into discomfort.  For reference I'm someone who can easily down a Chipotle burrito without blinking or feeling full.  I had the pastrami and the flavor wasn't there.  Bread was cheap, nothing enjoyable about the sandwhich.  The pickles on the side were the only thing decent about this place.

uYo6cYoa3JlgqrGeFxVvGA.text: The portion size is huge and waitstaff is very efficient.  Food however, is bland at best... Even the pastrami which they say is a specialty.

K_9SVymVt3n3FyGEHz67oQ.text: Attractive venue. Other than a great hostess the service was nothing to rave about. Seemed a little half hearted. Food was great tasting and loaded high but had to doctor my bacon and egg sandwich with ample dressing as it was quite dry. Prices are what you'd expect for a casino restaurant; too much. For my sandwich and a miniture bottle of water you'd usually get free while gambling on the floor, I paid nearly $20. Simply put, if you're looking for an experience, this is not the place.

lSMPp9ZdKvPaZDIF80kG4g.text: These sandwiches are huge and gigantic and can fill a king.  I love the pastrami sandwich. It is nice and juicy and I love the pickles.The service is pretty good fast.  One thing I also like is the New York Cheesecake, it is $10 however, but it is a brick. There is a ton of stuff there.  Anyways if you can not get it in New York, you can get it right in Las Vegas.

FrMcy6PjWlO7QRKlIWQ-RA.text: Like everything else on the strip, this place is very overpriced. The only good thing about this place is the pastrami sandwich. We ordered take out from this place twice. First time I bought a burger because I didn't think I'd care for the pastrami. The burger cost me round $16 with swiss cheese and NO fries. It was filling but had the same standard as a Denny's burger. My friends bought a pastrami and brisket sandwich. I tried both and only the pastrami was worth the money. We came back to this place later that night and ordered the pastrami, half roasted chicken, french fries, plain cheesecake and banana cream pie.   -Pastrami sandwich was delicious.  -Half roasted chicken was more like half roasted chicken breast in size. It was very dry and bland. We paid about $20 for this thing and it was NOT good. STAY AWAY FROM IT. The order came with what tasted like microwaved broccoli, just nasty. We wasted our money on this crap and could of gotten the $20 pastrami sandwich instead! -french fries were bout $4, they were OK but the serving size was small. -plain cheesecake, $6-$7. OK, but I've had better elsewhere. -Banana cream pie, I can't remember how much I paid for this but it was disappointing. I love banana cream pies and this one was not as sweet or creamy. Boo! Marie Cal makes better ones or Peter's Bakery.

37FvaMR5vfZ6PUSF3xDT2Q.text: if you're looking for pastrami, go here.  if you're looking for variety, dont go here.   the "sandwiches" are are literally bigger than my head. and my head is huge. so ... yeah.   the woodyallen was pretty good. but its just too much.  you pay 20 bucks for a sandwich you're not even going to finish.  sure, theres leftovers and all the meat you can eat when you come back to your hotel room.. but id rather pay 20 bucks for a complete meal that i can enjoy.

r0Bc9-9yn5UN_kz1XbTsuQ.text: Stays True to its NYC roots.  Lean, tasty pastrami and corned beef in fucktasticly big sandwiches.  The $16.95 Woody Allen sandwich is a pastrami/corned beef mix that might be bigger than Woody Allen's head (the sandwich is maybe 3 inches tall).  Highly recommend splitting the sandwich with someone else - even if they charge a couple bucks extra to do it.  Great horseradish tinged mustard.  Very good sour pickles.  They have a take-out spot that serves as a good fallback on busy sports weekends - you can just eat it in the sports book while watching the game.  So while this is NOT the place you want to be spending dinner in Vegas, it's a solid choice for lunch.  Especially if you don't live in a city with good Jewish deli.

JD7aKLhr3MZOj7UiBN03Qw.text: The service sucked.  Seriously, we almost got up and walked out it took so long to get someone to talk to us.   However... The food was DELICIOUS.  I had the Cheese Blintzes with sour cream and applesauce.  Need some comfort food for my hangover, and it definitely delivered.  The man had a sandwich bigger than my head which worked out well since he can't eat the bread anyway.   And they give you pickles while you're waiting for your food.  Funny pickles...

_qWs4fKJ8w8UxFfW3mVaMQ.text: Turkey burger and pickle good. Entrees are pricey.

4qv5K5oTwranZGhFQ2pZXw.text: Okay, why was there such a long wait?  We got so bored, we counted the empty seats in the place, and there were more empty seats than people waiting in line.  A former waitress, I thought maybe they were understaffed, but by time we were sat, they sat to capacity, so that confused me even more as to why we had to wait 20 minutes to be sat.  Our waitress took our order, but accidentally forgot to get my husband's.  It took us a few minutes to track her back down to get her to take his order, too, so his food came out later than the rest of us, which was kind of weird.  How do you forget the 4th person's order at a table.  Again, former waitress, and I don't get it.  That said, the grilled cheese and fries were fine.  I mean, it's grilled cheese.  I'm vegetarian so this wasn't the kind of place that caters to me, which is cool.  If you're into the meat, this is the place for you.  Their sandwiches were approximately nine inches tall, no joke.  It was unlike anything I've ever seen before.    I think I'd still like to try the real Carnegie Deli, though, because I somehow got the feeling this wasn't a good representation of the Carnegie name.  Service was lacking, wait time was illogical, and cleanliness wasn't the restaurant's forte.  I'll get back to you on all this after I check out another Carnegie Deli.

kma4Q995gzbuOHMEbpzDUA.text: Not feeling it at all....  My gf and I were looking for a quick bite before our Cirque show that night at the Mirage. We decided to stop by Carnegie's since it looked cheap and quick.   First of all, this restaurant is dirty. The floors were sticky and the table had dried mayo/mustard stuck on it. To be honest, that kind of set the tone for the rest of the meal. Anyway, I ordered the egg salad sandwich ($7.95)and my gf ordered the turkey sandwich ($14.99). The server asked my gf if she would like cheese, lettuce, tomatoes or anything else on the sandwich. Without thinking too much about it, she simply replied with "sure". We also had an order of Matzo balls in chicken broth ($6.95).  The soup came out first and it was pretty tasty. For those of you who don't know, Matzo balls are these giant meatballs made of dough but without the meat. It was tasty and hit the spot after a long 4 hour drive  from LA to Vegas. My egg salad sandwich tasted funky. I couldn't exactly put my finger on what it was, but it tasted as if it might have been spoiled or rotten. My gf's turkey sandwich was monstrous. I took a bite and it tasted pretty normal for a turkey sandwich.  When the bill came, they apparently charged extra for cheese, lettuce and tomatoes. $2 for the cheese, $1 for the lettuce and $1 for the tomatoes. What kind of a restaurant charges extra for lettuce, tomatoes, and cheese on a sandwich? Aren't sandwiches supposed to come with these things? We ended up paying almost $20 for a freakin' turkey sandwich. The same kind you get at Subway for $6.   All in all, we paid about $40 for two sandwiches and a bowl of soup. I would give it a lower rating if it weren't for the tasty Matzo ball soup. If you are staying in the Mirage, you can probably find better alternatives to Carnegie's.

gyqLWNaGbh4ZJH7crx3_oQ.text: Me and my buddies came here to eat before we went clubbing at Club Jet at the Mirage. We needed to eat quickly so we could get in line and actually get in. Being a guy it's harder to get into clubs, if you did not know that. It was pretty crowded in there so we got one of the last booth seats so it was nice. We sat down at a waiter came to get us our waters. Then he also brought us some salted pickles. The pickles were REALLY salty. Well they were too salty for me anyways, but my friends liked them.   Then i got the pastrami sandwich on white bread. It was like $14 bucks....cough cough. I thought it was going to be a small sandwich that was good. And because i was in Vegas i expected it to be expensive. We did not expect the sandwiches to be so big. I tried to pick up the whole sandwich and i was stuffing my face.   After a good 5 mins i finished the first half. I had to use a fork to eat some of it because many of it came out of the sandwich and onto my plate. I could only eat about 3/4 of the sandwich by the time i was full.   The service was okay. It was really busy so it was kind of hard to get service and some more pickles. We were in and out of there pretty quick and we planned to come back, but we never did. Overall, a pretty good place if you are craving a pastrami or corn beef sandwich in Vegas.

y7uU79DtzXQeCJ1-mv7xKA.text: I returned and tried the liverwurst on white bread again.  TOO MUCH LIVERWURST. Sigh.  I feel bad wasting so much.  I wish they had half portions available.

PvPQqxGxzwukCkb_-xXNvQ.text: 2.5 stars  I was not impressed with breakfast here as it was quite average.. We weren't happy with the service either.. they were less professional than other restaurants/people we came across  We ordered french toast, one corned beef omelette, and two pastrami omelettes.  I didn't even finish my omelette because there wasn't really anything special to it! No vegetables whatsoever.. I would have thought they woulda made it fancy somehow

d6kbqPxxsaRroZ0t5FKKTw.text: 1 pound of meat for $13!  4 of us ordered 1 pastrami sandwich and 1 corn beef sandwich + 2 basic salad. Free pickles when we sat down. One sandwich is enough meat for 4 people(we have some small eater in our group). Total cost for about $40. Pretty good considering  this is on the strip.  The pastrami sandwich is filled with meat, sliced thin and then stacked high between rye bread (very traditional). The meat has a hint of smoke, has good flavor with  a generous spice rub around the edge, but not too salty. A little bit of fat on the sandwich makes it juicy without being too heavy. I cannot help but compared it with Schwartz in Montreal. Schwartz's meat has more smokiness, while this is milder. Carnegie Deli's pastrami however a little more salty. I find mustard give a good kick to Schwartz's, but not needed for Carnegie's version. Both version are highly enjoyable.  The corned beef sandwich is also filled with meat, stacked high between rye bread. The meat is fatty but not greasy and not heavy. I am a little puzzled by how they achieved this...  The pickles are salty but not too tart. This is different from other pickles that I have. I cannot say I prefer it to ordinary pickle, but it is quite good in its own right.  The salad is big, but simple. We ordered that because we feel guilty downing 2 pounds of meat:)

H_OYPg_UY0-3Hmu2-aujfQ.text: The sandwiches are GIGANTIC. Unfortunately I had just finished a burrito from Chipotle (yes the whole thing, I'm a growing woman) so I only had their soup special... but was still slobbering over everyone else's gigantic sandwiches.   Next time....

QKUUTuSbLRBoLMKQWh7ISw.text: The corned beef is delicious but to get it on one of their mile high sandwiches is just silly.  I ordered one with corned beef, smoked turkey, swiss cheese and coleslaw. The individual parts were very good, but as a sandwich it ends up becoming a waste when you try to deconstruct it.   The corned beef hash is amazing. Potato cakes are strange - they almost have a hint of sweetness which was a turn off for me. Coleslaw is delicious. French fries are on the better side of standard, but you get a gigantic plate as an order - easily enough for three people to share.  Lines are long and service is slow so be prepared.

w2PZrCCnMz1isIjGDYJ5_g.text: My husband and I stumbled upon this fabulous place. I could not believe that they actually built this at the Mirage. The restraunt in pretty tiny, but I expected that since it is in a hotel. The staff were very friendly and were able to seat us fairly quickly. When we were seated, we noticed that the tables were super close together which was kind of lame. I had a grilled cheese, and my husband had the corned beef, both were excellent. We will totally be coming back here when we visit Vegas again.

pMGSizFVP_J9GnQGYK9SJg.text: Gluten free friendly yippee-best pastrami sandwich ever stacked super high not greasy full of flavor the thousand island dressing which I asked for on the side was super delicious. I still prefer to be waited on instead you had to go up to the counter to Order.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yumo

MzV5GWmniPUm7ZJmGJZZ4w.text: I'm not sure about some of these reviews...you were surprised your $25 sandwhich was huge and their specialty and NOT the standard small one you thought you were getting?  I got the Woody Allen and destroyed it.    Was delicious and fresh.  Hadn't been there before the change, but I think  would have preferred wait service for the whole meal instead of ordering in advance.  Would have allowed me to tip properly.  Poor staff must not make much.  Fries were good, cole slaw as well...ordered two cream sodas to wash it down...and Dr. Brown's was perfect.

WWZqOyaQI7LUBuCgQKlVfA.text: This restaurant deserves 4 stars for the portions alone.  Though it will never match the True Carnegie Deli in New York.  this sandwich is still very good for Las Vegas.  Regardless of what you order, you will be bringing home leftovers.  Because of this, this prices are fine because it's as if you're buying two meals at once.  Carnegie, and the experience of the food, really depends on what you order and your taste buds.  I recommend the pastrami and/or corned beef for the best experience, and turkey if none of those intrigue your taste buds.    If you are in the area and want to fill up and not be disappointed, order one of their sandwiches.  There may be a wait, and it will cost you about $20, but you will be served a full day's meal on your plate.

cTjQ9fSI3BSSCu-ne4naQA.text: Located in Mirage casino, New York style Jewish deli. Cafe like dinning. Order food at front counter. They give you receipt and number. Sit where you want. Server brings out your order. A bit pricey but well worth the taste. I ordered pastrami (half sandwich deal) along with potato salad and comes with a pickle. Pickle was bland but sandwich was amazing! I mean really delicious. Highly recommend!

3tjfMqveBB54Vbcf-CjR-g.text: Great place if you love big sandwiches or sandwiches in general.  My wife and I shared the Woody Allen!  The pickles are great!  For dessert, we shared the strawberry cheesecake and it hit the spot!  It's pricey but you expect that on the strip.  Don't forget the pickles!  All in all a great meal!

kJcVDFSGUULPyJ0sVVoVog.text: Went on a Sunday night around 8:00 pm and there was no waiting.  Went up to the order counter and asked for a Reuben, side of potato salad, side of cole slaw.  Got my number and headed over to a table with the lady.  Friendly server came over with our order and a share plate, which was unexpected and very nice.  Their Reuben is open-faced, which is very unusual (although we knew what we were getting), and although tasty, I missed the grilled quality of the bread.  The meat was also a little dry, and the sandwich skimpy on the sauerkraut and dressing.  Finally, while a decent size, for $25 I expected a larger sandwich, especially with all the comments about how huge this thing is supposed to be.  Sides were better than I expected - I'm usually disappointed with potato salad nearly everywhere I go (including Katz's in NYC), so this was a big plus for me.  Overall a decent meal, but I expected better.

BD3XFBppsUiCBcJVRfCacQ.text: I too, have been someone that has eaten at Carnegie each time during Vegas trips. It has definitely gone downhill.  Ordered a pastrami sandwich to share with the hubs, 1 beer, 1 fountain drink, and side of fries and it came to $41!   Yes, the bread is great, pastrami fresh. But they messed up our order (like what the other reviews had said). They forgot to bring our fries, then forgot to add cheese on the sandwich. I think the server got the wrong receipt for our table. Service has not been that bad before.  The biggest feedback I hope they will understand is the ordering up front and finding a table, and wait for your food to be delivered to your table. Please stop doing that, and hopefully the orders will be served correctly.   I'm hesitant to come back on my next trip to Vegas.

6phnHSncKb_sY0wBc2TFsw.text: Ah, Carnegie Deli, we were craving a tall corn beef on rye and a bowl of matzo ball soup, ala NYC. We arrived early before showtime to beat the crowds, mission accomplished, no crowds like last year.  $17.99 for a Corn Beef and $41 bucks later, we were greeted by an enormous sandwich as expected. UNFORTUNATELY THE SANDWICH ARRIVED ON STALE RYE BREAD WITH DRY, TOUGH CORN BEEF.  Not the consistent standard  we have come to expect from Carnegie. We know now why there are no crowds, sadly, please say it ain't so Carnegie!  Mgmt. help. We won't be back.

sqKu_pddJ_qH0yN9nNfj4w.text: Ordered the pastrami sandwich, brisket sandwich, fries and the chicken noodle soup. The pastrami sandwich was great but the brisket was very bland. Chicken noodle soup taste like it was from a can. The pickle they give you with the sandwich is nice and crisp. Use my mlife rewards to get one of the sandwiches free.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef brisket
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hot pastrami

-MNUNczn0wa-FVD5M1n5pw.text: On the second night of my staycation with my brother and dad who flew in from New York, we were up for a New York deli. We decided on trying the Carnegie Deli, a restaurant I must of passed by a thousand times.    Carnegie Deli has the distinction of being one of those restaurants where a nice overpowering deli smell leads guests to the establishment. As soon as I walk in the Mirage I could smell the deli smell beyond BLT, Starbucks,  and the Sugar Factory. The issue is that everytime that I looked at their menu, the prices were overpowering. Today we'd give it a try.    There are two cues for Carnegie Deli. One is for take out and the other is for dining in.     The dining room is spacious.  The restrooms are outside in the casino. Throughout the restaurant are pictures showing the history of Carnegie Deli.     Carnegie Deli has a long history. It was established in 1937 at the intersection of 7th Avenue at 55th Street in Midtown Manhattan.Throughout the years they have received accolades. In 1979, NY Times critic Mimi Sheraton named Carnegie Deli the #1 pastromi in New York City. Years later, in 2009 Dr. Phil gave a shout out that Carnegie Deli makes the best sandwiches later. On March, 26 2013 I am giving a shout out that Carnegie Deli made the thickest pastrami sandwich that I ever ate.     The Carnegie Deli website claims that all of their sandwiches are stuffed with at least one pound of meat. Finishing the pastrami on rye bread was one of the biggest dining challenges that I faced in awhile. Part of the problem is that I am not crazy over pastrami. Especially the $17 price. Carnegie offers other sandwiches that include Corn beef ($17.99), beef or brisket ($17.99), chop liver ($17.99), roast beef ($17.99), turkey ($17.99), bologne or salami ($14.99), shrimp salad ($12.99), and egg salad ($10.99). If I return I will most likely order the shrimp salad sandwich. If they are serving me a pound of that stuff I will up my rating to 4 stars. With the sandwiches are pickles. All three of us shared a bowl of french fries-a grand portion indeed. For a beverage there is fountain Coke or bottles of Dr. Brown's soda.    Carnegie Deli's motto is that if you can finish your meal we've done something wrong. My motto is that when a sandwich costs $17, I am going to finish my meal. Unfortunately I was so stuffed that I passed over trying their renoun cheesecake.  That could be for another time.  The Yelp 100. Review 49.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. This is the largest pastrami sandwich that I ever ate.

F-ficgWQiTXQOkH_-P03fg.text: What the?  NYC:  "Next".  A pause.  "Hey buddy, get to the back of the line if you don't know what you want"  Vegas:  "Good afternoon, what would you like to have"  A pause.  "Take your time"  NYC:  Open the grease soaked paper wrapping and expose a four inch pile of juicy pastrami, brisket, or tongue on thin sliced rye.  Slather on the mustard.  Grab some pickles.  Get primal animal.  Vegas:  An inch and a half of over steamed, dry edge pastrami on thick sliced rye to keep your fingers clean.  Mustard in a squirt bottle and a pickle served in your personal dish.  An insult to the venerable institution that is arguably serves the best pastrami in the US (sorry, Katz's and Langer's).  Straight to it, post renovation in late 2014, things have changed.  Once known for crazy massive sandwiches with six inches of meat, a quarter head of lettuce, portions are now manageable.  All good as prices have also fallen.  They now offer a half sandwich, side and drink combo that a normal human can consume.  Great.   The menu is greatly reduced with many Jewish deli staples now gone.  Predesigned sandwiches with various meats are gone.  Sad yes, but the ultimate problem, the food isn't the same quality.  The legendary pastrami, while just as flavorful, sweet and salty deep beef flavor with the perfect oily mouth feel, has dry edges.  The brisket, suffers the same problem.  Pickles taste like they've been drained instead of being pulled fresh from a crock and brine.  While many times better than your local supermarket deli, it's just doesn't measure to past greatness.  The Vegas location never captured the True spirit of Carnegie Deli's NYC location with its gruff service and no nonsense, good eats, unfortunately the difference is now more than just its personality and geography.

T_mqNkfQJXeAJL3HGc-F6A.text: We made it a point to come back to the Carnigee after out last great experience.  What a mistake.  Last time we had table service, this time we ordered at the counter, like McDonald's.  Unlike McDonald's,  the order taker completely messed up my order.  The the order came, it was wrong,  the quality has dropped significantly as well as the size of the sandwich  was much smaller.  The only bright spot was our server, Gabriella. She went above and beyond to make our dining experience  enjoyable.   I hope this is not the way the run their restaurant in NYC.  We will be scratching this restaurant off our must go to list for Los Vegas.

WDKol5vv-i7rIQP6IUhlbA.text: Watched huge portions go by.  We ordered a bowl of matzo ball soup and enjoyed it.  Also had some cheese crepes that were delicious.

piBde4_amVgiP0SjDl3K4Q.text: This used to be a great, kitschy place to have a bite to eat on The Strip. That was then... now most of the portions have been downsized but still go for the same inflated price. The ordering process is changed, the serving staff smaller and the entire process far more impersonal. The sandwiches used to be picture worthy and awe inspiring in their triple decker goodness but again, that was then. The Turkey Club, Matzo Ball Soup or Cheesecake are still great picks if you want to drop forty bucks before soft-drinks and parking (yes, parking), otherwise, there are plenty of other high-priced fairly quick eateries nearby.

oRuvaEsAGKezB2l6_PUmDQ.text: This place is freakin' expensive!! I only ate here because my boss wanted my team to meet here for breakfast. The breakfast is OK but not exceptional. However, I had a slice of strawberry cheesecake and it was a giant piece of DELICIOUS!!  The other breakfast places inside The Mirage always have huge wait lines but turnover is fast in this diner so it was always easy to get a table.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Strawberry cheesecake which was super yums!!
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Big breakfast during my second visit...it was much better than the breakfast sandwich I had the day before.

-NfXK3txG1spP14qwE5_Hw.text: Carnegie Deli is somewhat a guilty pleasure of ours when my hubby and I visit Vegas. The dishes remind him of Brooklyn and me of Russia. While some of the dishes are not extremely authentic, the flavors are just good enough to give you a taste of the Eastern European and Jewish cuisine.  During this stay, I enjoyed a bowl of pierogi. Of course nothing comes close to my mom's homemade ones, but the flavors were not too bad. I didn't really like the dough, because it reminded me of the cheap deep frozen ones you can buy in a supermarket. But the filling was quite nice.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pierogi; yummy, but not authentic

qvxHF_KlUCKEQfSHIy6Bkg.text: Great serving size, actually extremely large serving size. The smallest sandwich offered here is a pound of meat! Crazy!  I love coming here, fresh meat, friendly staff and quick service.  My reason for only giving 4 stars, is the seating in here is accommodating for a lot of people so tables are very close together. I felt as if I was enjoying lunch with people in both sides of us.   Overall great experience, a little expensive but most of Vegas is. I'd go back the next time I'm in town.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pastrami on rye
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Turkey club

-A5Au9MGBzJ5TFxiZMuGKQ.text: Located in the Mirage casino.  I heard good things from a coworker that swears by the Corned Beef here. I decided to check this out last time I was in Vegas and was not disappointed.   The Woody Allen is a massive delicious corned beef and pastrami sandwich. The corned beef and pastrami are piled high here so sharing is definitely recommend. At $24 a sandwich I thought it was good, but just a little overpriced.  I am comparing this to Langer's and Canters in LA, definitely ranks #1 out of those three places so far in my opinion,  Fries were good, but nothing special. I ordered a Lemonade with my meal, and I don't know if it was because I was just thirsty, but it was most excellent.   Would definitely come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The infamous Woody Allen

Z59Ye8dNXIE1zFssDVVxGA.text: A very disappointing and expensive experience. We decided to stop in for brunch and went with some very simple menu items which I will give you a rundown on..   Matzo ball soup with noodles and chicken - absolutely no chicken in the broth. Matzo balls were flavorless along with the broth. I had to keep adding salt and pepper to get any type of flavor here.   Potato pancake - also flavorless, and extremely greasy. Another salt and pepper showering.   Coffee - bland, waiter never came around for refills.   Cheesecake -  actually pretty good, but it was THIRTEEN DOLLARS for a disappointing size slice. If you're going to charge thirteen bucks for a slice, make it big.   We've been here before and the sandwiches are good, but also overpriced. I would only suggest coming here if you're in the mood for a traditional Jewish deli sandwich, and want to light some money on fire.

5j1oxlZo1jF-VhJb8S5ahw.text: I ordered "thick ham" and it's not thick at all! Ice cold butter to spread on cold toast. Not a good experience for my first time.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Butter is ice cold. And toast isn&#39;t warm, so this is the best I could do to spread it.

48fnraTcq9wqWL0tc4Tapg.text: Food just like the one that used to be in New York Coty without the filth and long lines. Only thing missing was the half sour pickles - otherwise as authentic a NY deli that you can ever find. Meat piled high on excellent soft rye, even Had French toast that was delicious. Found the Matza ball to not have much flavor but still enjoyed overall meal. $40 for 3 people and located i. The Mirage hotel on Las Vegas blvd.

zldM7xiKDZX7mI4IYltkKA.text: Food is great!  I love to eat here when I am in Las Vegas.  Prices are a little high, but you won't leave hungry.  I always get the hot pastrami on rye.  Its so big you have to start eating it with a fork.  Pretty amazing fries too!  I do miss the old days when it was totally table service instead of walk up!

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

2sI3_X-7ASI_jwQedKEIxA.text: This place is ridiculously good. Dont go here with food your belly you need to be very hungry cause the portions are massive to where two people can eat one order. Like the Turkey cobb sandwich is about 7 inches high and 24.00 of pure Girth, plus they give you a bowl or plate full of fries its way to much for one person. I had a smaller turkey sandwich for 18.00 but its got 3 inches of fresh turkey breast thickly cut on your sandwich.  The Frankfurter is 12 inches long and wide. My wife had a slice of chocolate cake that will make your head my wife said the chocolate cake can cure the worst sugar craving. Amazing and fun place to eat.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The most killer tasting chocolate cake. Amazing!
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Huge turkey sandwich

9t2HkKILV9W-NUuK0CT6Gg.text: First thing I said was, lets have lunch at Carnegie.  I always make it a point to eat here whenever I'm in Vegas.  Driving here from LA made us super hungry so we were happy to sit down for lunch.   Located near the sports book in Mirage hotel, is this small deli.  You order at the cashier and they give you a numbered table tent to place on your table.  The server will deliver your food to your table.  The 3 of us shared 1 pastrami sandwich, fries (ask for extra crispy, trust me), 2 chicken soups with matzo ball, and 2 soft drinks.  It was a whopping $50 but all worth it.  It was so much food, really.  Only 2 of us ate soup but us 2 could've shared 1 soup - the bowl and Matzo ball was huge.  Not sure how we ended up with 6 pieces of bread (we must've asked for extra bread) but we had enough meat to comfortably make 3 sandwiches - 1 for each of us.  Sharing is caring so don't be afraid to share!  That way you don't waste food.  Only bummer thing is the new parking rates in Vegas.  We were staying at Aria (MGM family hotel) but didn't bother checking in yet cause it was too early so we had to pay the $8 parking fee at Mirage.  Had we already checked in, parking would've been free if you park at any MGM property.  Daily parking rate for MGM hotel guests is $17 or $18 for unlimited parking at any MGM property.  If you have m-LIFE Pearl status or higher, daily parking rate is waived.  The food here is so good.  You have to come here to eat at least once!  In the end we were all happy with extra full tummies.

ZUNB5v8fAPH6xe0l7uvatQ.text: Very good but not quite the size of the original in NY both in portions and overall menu choices. My most recent visit did not have the greatest service. I paid for a drink and I had a lot of difficulty getting my server to come by and pour refills for me. She just wouldn't circulate and then somehow didn't see me trying to wave her over multiple times. The food was delicious. I've had the Woodie Allen and the Bacon Turkey club as well as the Matso Ball soup with golden noodles. I could eat that soup all day long. the woody Allen wasn't quite as big as the last one I had at the now closed NY location but I'd still eat it again. I love Jewish deli!

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

NCN088cEiek3jKnjVS9QYQ.text: Very good the woody Allen is a must  Try also the club mostoball soup as well is great the cornish is ok wish they had brown gravy but it's still great food

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Turkey with cheese a plan ruben

-d1t9cLQNJCP9_WtFPqykA.text: For finding this place in desperation for breakfast food, it wasn't too shabby. It wasn't nearly as crowded as some of the other restaurants in mirage and it's probably partially because it's not in the main area. We followed the signs for the deli and found it. It's not entirely closed off from the casino but there's a short wall so you can still see out.   There was a small line waiting to order and it didn't take too long. The menu is above the ordering counter, on a screen and a written menu. You order and then get a number to take back to your seat and wait for the food. They also have servers that come to the tables to fill up coffees, bring waters and whatever else you might need.   The coffee was surprisingly good for being a deli/cafe type place in a casino. There was Dijon on the table and you can get cholula by request. Everything was pretty good and much better than the buffet. Not a bad place at all!

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Blueberry muffin
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Egg and sausage brew sandwich
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Egg and sausage

mjwonpOHMjxxttFzxqwEXw.text: It's walk up, self-service when ordering; waited a looong time before a cashier took our order. She was pretty rude as well. You are asked to enter your tip on the payment, *before* sitting down to be served. Just a little pushy, even for LV!  The food is decent but $25 for a Reuban sandwich!! -Not recommended -

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1iR2K1nFNpd0wlYDLsYakg.text: Carnegie New York Deli at the Mirage is AUTHENTIC & AWESOME! My Vegas trip was going ok but then I found the DELI :) I cannot describe how tall and delicious my sandwich was. You will have to try it yourself. I ordered the Woody Allen & BOOM it was a huge pastrami & corned beef sandwich with the best tasting Rye bread, pickles & brown mustard ever! Meat lovers dream! I had to share it with my big brother and we were both full. I missed visiting New York but having Carnegie in Las Vegas was a special treat & I loved it!  Cheesecake yes!  Get that to go!

lWW7aRh0AaVCBvNlTmjFnw.text: The pastrami sandwich is True to it's  New Yorks roots. Absolutely delicious lean pastrami  piled high on moist jewish rye. And of course served with a pickle. Course mustard nearby to add a little zing to the meat. Let it be known that this sandwich did cost 19.50 with tax. It is a full meal so worth the money and the only place to get Carnegie Deli food since the New York store closed.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

cZGPNCEj_B_3b5KNK7DcFQ.text: I went to the Carnegie Deli in New York many years ago and was disappointed that it closed.   I decided to check Carnegie at the Mirage and I'm glad I did !!!  My friend and I split a corned beef on rye with Sauerkraut, potato salad and coleslaw.   I thought everything was excellent. The corned beef sandwich was big. And it wasn't too salty. Sauerkraut was not too tangy and the potato salad was pretty good. The potatoes could have been a little softer but the taste was great.    This is one of the places I would return to if given the chance.

iL3DKGlgQ2Y_BgGv2TtUMg.text: The pastrami is as good as I remember (which means it rates as some of the best ever) but they lose points on three issues: 1) They had Dr. Brown's Black Cherry and Cream Sodas, but NOT Cel-Ray. 2) They included only one dill pickle, not a plate of dills and half sours 3) No cole slaw  It's been years since I had lunch at the original Manhattan location, but I'm pretty sure I had my sandwich with Cel-Ray, cole slaw and half-sour pickles.  Still, it was good to have their excellent pastrami again after all these years.  However, due to the three issues I listed above, I can only give the Las Vegas location three stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. God I miss this back in New York!

LNJmP1hG4CbPjotjwsHTpA.text: This was our first stop in Vegas after getting off the plane and walking the strip. We hadn't eaten all day and this was the perfect spot. Me being a first timer in Vegas, and a major foodie, was SO happy with the atmosphere and the food. Portions are HUGE and so worth the price. I got the Ruben and we also got the corn beef hash. Both were to die for ! This will be my first stop in Vegas again when we come back !

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Corn beef hash &amp; The Ruben

kCAp_WWuCiCCX3va-Rcc1Q.text: Visiting the Las Vegas output was a flashback to the original in NY with better service. No frills and probably wouldn't make the trip there unless I was with a Carnegie die hard or was already at the Mirage for something else.  The sandwich itself was just like the original with slightly softer bread.  Stick to the basics here and just get a sandwich and fries.  The potato pancakes were not a good deal -- $4 for something rather tiny made us wish we stuck to fries.  The matzo ball soup was okay, but not as good as I expected. I prefer my matzo ball soup direct from a NY deli.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States

zsFi2A7E2oEpkuSj9Sxd3w.text: Carnegie Deli makes one hell of a Pastrami.  I was basically bone ass wasted on the first night of a five-night vacation when the alcohol surging through my veins instructed me that I was in serious need of a True NYC Pastrami. Enter Carnegie Deli at The Mirage.   The Deli itself was bright and packed (if memory serves me correctly). I barked out the words "Woody Allen" to the affable employee taking orders and I was soon handed a paper bag full of what felt like a bowling ball inside. I paid some other person roughly $20.00 and headed off to The Park MGM in order to eat (and sober up).  These portions are insane. This sandwich could feed a person three times over. That isn't to say it wasn't good. In fact, it was mesmerizing! After Katz's in LES, this had to be my favorite Pastrami in NYC before it closed to the chagrin of greater New York due to family infighting and outrageous rent.   Two pieces of rye are stuffed to their breaking point with soft, salty and oh-so-lush brined & smoked Brisket. This sandwich is absoultely NO JOKE when combined with the supplied Deli Mustard. Somehow pickles made their way into the bag which was a nice tangy change up to the saltiness and savory of the hot sandwich.   I ate twice what I should have and still had enough to last another meal. This Pastrami evokes great emotion. I want another right now.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Woody Allen.

Wrt6oLWhHB2K4Zo4iS9VOQ.text: My first impression was that the place looked run down.  They sure could use a make over.  (So does the casino in total.)  There was nothing good in the food we ordered.  We had  two turkey sandwiches on wheat bread.  The bread was the same as grocery store bread and not fresh.  There was a lot of turkey.  Very dry.  The mayo was self serve on the table, not refrigerated.  The French fries were from the same grocery store freezer as the bread.  The cola was OK.  $58 and we couldn't eat it.  I wish we had eaten at Starbucks down the hall.  Big disappointment.

ssawHmwvKa9d8PzU3fiXiw.text: Food and waitress are good but I wasn't sure about cashier her name was Jennifer.  I was visit to there this morning and when I order at the cash register I got mad. She wasn't polite at all. I felt  more then that but I only like to say that.

zDxGrc38FtQmZRwvVUT5eQ.text: Want a huge freakin' sandwich at 1:00am?!   Carnegie Deli is the place to be...  My brother-in-law purchased a pastrami sandwich that looked like it could feed a family of five.  He ate 1/2 and saved the rest, and he can put down some food.  Huge value here.  Food tasted pretty great as well.  Bacon cheeseburger was juicy and the bacon was crisp and salty, just the way it should be.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bacon!
Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Holy pastrami!

0rDmgFFlH2Uwm6P1DSsC5w.text: Beware of the server who wears gloves.  She cleans the tables, touches dirty dishes, sets tables, and serves customers their food-- all with the same pair of latex gloves.  Pretty disgusting!

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Be wary of the waitress who wears gloves. She cleans the tables and serves food - - all with the same pair of gloves.  Pretty disgusting!

II9O22Xml5g1hfgZbTcadQ.text: Huge sandwiches!   But it's not like the old Carnegie in NYC.  The corn beef is not the same. The quality of the meat, how it is prepared, sliced and served is not the same. But it is priced like Katz deli in NYC.  I would not recommend unless you dying for a deli corn beef sandwich.   The cheese cake is less than average.

JnjlGj8wIhsTYqFj2xiNKQ.text: What used to be a great place has become ho hum. Lower quality meat, smaller portions (which are still large but price is way up there)  $31.00 for 1 sandwich with fries, 2 drinks. The change to cafeteria style is silly. 4 servers standing around with not even quarter of restaurant full.

3U-V2o4QsjrrziRUFlaZWg.text: My husband and I ate here around 10am on Tuesday morning. It wasn't too busy and we were seated right away. Some guy took our drink order and then we waited quite a while for someone to take our food order. I ordered the eggs with potatoes and a bagel with cream cheese. My husband got a western omelette with cheese. I believe the OJ is squeezed fresh because it was delicious. A large is $7, but no shocker in Vegas.  Our food arrived pretty quickly. My eggs were sunny side up, but 2 out of three still had some runny white parts, so I sent them back. They returned quickly and were perfect. The eggs were yummy, the potatoes had great seasoning and weren't greasy at all. My bagel was so tasty and the cream cheese was amazing. I realized I'd probably never had cream cheese that wasn't from Philadelphia's box, so I really enjoyed it. My husband said his omelette was really good and our waitress was very nice, so we were happy. I would definitely go back.

MljO9sBLWA-UeFiFsEoZBA.text: A bit dissappointing. I know its Vegas and all but 17$ for a half sandwich, drink, potato chips... Just cause they give you a lot of meat doesnt mean the quality should be any less important. Bigger is not always better. (Note I ordered turkey on white / perhaps their signature dishes are better)

WoIdF-CVLvS04Q4M207vIg.text: I got the monster 2lb pastrami and corned beef sandwich...the Woody Allen ($19).  You get a huge sandwich but unfortunately, there wasn't much flavor.  It comes with a side of 3 pickles and that's it.  It's just slabs of meat in between 2 small pieces of bread.  I had to use a lot of mustard because the meat was kind of dry.  In all honesty, the Reuben at my work commissary and the Pastrami at Subway is more flavorful.  But I don't regret getting it because it was definitely an experience trying to eat it.  When they brought it out, people were staring at it and 3 people actually asked me what it was.  I only got through 1lb and had to take the rest home.  My wife got the turkey burger ($11) which she said was bland, dry and had no flavor. Even though I gave it 3 stars, I would like to go back sometime and try their Reuben.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Woody allen..2lbs of pastrami and corned beef

b61JXAPIETnw19ZL6b07Hg.text: HUGEEEEEE pastrami sandwich. Honestly, America, this is why your fat. I shared this is a guy and we still had leftover. I had to take out about half the meat in my half and take it to-go. They're super nice though, gave me extra bread so I could make a whole new sandwich with my leftovers.  It was pretty good, not something I would be dying to eat when in Vegas but definitely glad I got to take a picture with it,..haha

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. and that&#39;s just half..

Pi4ILl0EwWSK37QmzZ-AOg.text: I ordered take out. And it took an hour to get my food even though I ordered French toast and my sister ordered bacon. I don't understand why it took so long. I asked the guy at the register and he was pretty unhelpful he just kept saying, your order will be right out. We finally got our order after an hour and only half of it was there. We had to wait a few more minutes before the bacon came out. Although the food was good, the service was pretty crappy.

OPHrDUfGiJ5w18qMQop9gw.text: I've had breakfast here, and dessert.  As someone else said, the desserts are not that great, dried up sugar bombs.  Breakfast wasn't much better, very greasy.    The Mirage really needs to get a decent cafe for breakfast, like Avenue 24 at MGM Grand.

Buru3ANdk59EUL_1KLgT0A.text: Not for me...at least, not alone.  Ridiculously large portions and a $3 up charge to share. The Woody Allen (corned beef and pastrami) was fine but cut the size on half along with the price and I'd give you another two stars. The meat was good. Too bad I will not come back to pay $20+ for a sandwich I can't finish.

fpOAGiLndhA9f6jixrXfXw.text: This was the grossest omlet I've ever had. No joke it tasted like burnt motor oil was poured on it. I asked for my home fries crispy and the just gave me half regular potatoes and half the small burnt leftover pieces.  I will give them credit that when I returned the omlet the new one came back tolerable,  but by then my appetite was gone.

photos.caption: Photo of Carnegie - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The &#34;side&#34; of bacon. Would rather 3 pieces of thick cut good stuff than 17 pieces of this crap.

gEg7fC5_2ahc7CV4HCLH9Q.text: Worst service possible. This place must only be busy because of convenience to hotel guests. Took 30 minutes to get my food, though other people that ordered before me and directly after me got their food within 15 minutes. All the tables were dirty, sat at a dirty table and someone came to wipe it down 10 minutes later, no apology. They literally put a pile of meat on 2 half slices of bread and put a bowl with whatever side you order on the plate. This should not take 30 minutes. Brought me the food with the incorrect side dish, it was the wrong one, but no apologies, nor were there any apologies for the delays. Multiple other people had not received their food. The wait staff is running around like crazy but I'm not sure what they were actually doing since no one was getting their food and there were plates of food  just waiting to go out. They want you to tip at the register, and then give the server the receipt, I didn't tip at the register, preferring to pay cash after assessing the level of service. I'm not sure if this contributed to the service I received but from what I saw it probably did.  I ordered a cheesecake slice to go when I ordered my food. After 45 minutes, hadn't received it, and the waitress checked on the table next to me but never stopped to check on me, so I requested a refund, which they tell me will take a few days. Don't waste your money or time. Go to LVB Burgers, customer service was much better.

fwZCcZwwIOXLgZER00oTrA.text: The Carnegie Delicatessen & Restaurant is an overpriced place to eat located on the main floor of the Mirage hotel.  As I was coming home from a night out on the strip,  I decided to grab a late night snack to take back up to my room.  I went with a pastrami sandwich on rye, which turned out to be a vacation changing mistake.   The sandwich came with a lot of meat and tasted okay, but it was definitely not worth the hefty price.  A few hours after eating the sandwich I was extremely sick, and remained sick for almost two days strait.  I was hardly able to eat anything during my remaining time in Las Vegas, and my sickness made it difficult for me to enjoy the final day of my vacation.    I will not be easting at the Carnegie Delicatessen & Restaurant again, and will look for better food at a more reasonable price the next time that I am in Las Vegas.

5mgrCQ0C02L6vWemjSO5Gg.text: Not the real thing, but almost. Overpriced, like most things in Las Vegas, but definitely the best deli in the area.

oPo6CT1AOuaOI4LsNrDdmQ.text: I'm from NY, but have never had the pleasure to eat at the original Carnegie deli, so I wanted to try it while staying at The Mirage.  Ordered a BLT, and it was huge! It was definitely more than I can eat, I wish the hubs and I had split the sandwich, but they charge you a extra $3 to share.  I don't understand that at all.  Hubs had the Ruben, it was delish, but again, it was huge.  Ate there late one night after a show, and the staff was super friendly and helpful.  It was close to 11pm, and there was no wait, and food came quickly.  It was pricey, just like all the restaurants in the hotels on the strip. Decent sandwiches, but be aware of the portions.

ZFEDl6Rqq3FoEPypW0xw8A.text: Think of this review more as a 3.45 if anything.  I came to Carnegie some time back but before I was a religious yelper. When a buddy suggested we get sandwiches for lunch right when we got into town, I had no idea we would find our way back to this place.   All I remember are the portions are gigantic ($3 sharing fee) and at this time, I was thinking with my stomach than my head and ordered something solo (mind you, I had a MAJOR case of food poisoning the day prior so I was feeling like I was running on empty). I got the Woody Allen which comes with pastrami and corned beef.  When it came out, it was STACKED to the max. I forgot how to eat it. It went well with the deli mustard that sits at the table.   Disappointments this time around: - One of my friends got the beef tongue and said it was flavorless. There was nothing in the sandwich in the self that would make it "saucy" to eat... and the way this beef tongue was, there didn't appear to be any natural juices.  - The portion sizes are a bit wacky. A side of fries for $6 (which were cooked perfectly) was a pretty good size. For about $5 we also got a small bowl of potato salad and a small baked potato that didn't even come out with any butter, sour cream or chives!  The waitress noticed that we waited a long haul without getting any of the items we requested (sauce, extra place settings, etc.) so she came by, graciously apologized, and got us an extra order of fries. That's great customer service there.  I'm not sure under what pretenses I'll come back here, I'm sure there are other pastrami places to explore in Vegas!

krDmmECfAldsXqZVqMj7Fg.text: I came here for a late lunch while I waited for my friend to arrive from her flight to Vegas. There was a short wait but then I was seated and my drink order taken. I wasn't sure who my waitress was as I wasn't really greeted. The prices here seem really high. It was $9 for the grilled cheese I ordered, and it came with nothing. I thought about ordering fries, but a side was $6! I saw some girls with a huge plate of fries and I didn't want that many anyway. I decided to order a potato pancake instead. It came out first and it was huge. It was burned around the edges and was just ok. The sandwich came out next and it was not done correctly. It was on rye (yuck) when I ordered wheat. It was also tiny for $9 and coming with nothing. I wasn't checked on for my entire meal and couldn't catch the waitress's eye, so I wasn't able to send it back. I needed to get back to the room to greet my friend, so I didn't have time to order another. I ended up just eating the potato pancake.
